questions.text: False about the period of pathogenesis is:

options.label: B
options.text: Begins with the entry of disease agent in the susceptible host

options.label: C
options.text: May be modified by immunization and chemotherapy

options.label: D
options.text: Hosts reaction to infection is not predictable

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Screening has no role Pathogenesis phase –

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. The pathogenesis phase begins with the entry of the disease "agent" in the susceptible human host. Option: C. The further events in the pathogenesis phase are clear-cut in infectious diseases, i.e., the disease. agent multiplies and induces tissue and physiological changes, the disease progresses through a period of incubation and later through early and late pathogenesis. The outcome of the disease may be recovery, disability, or death. Intervention measures such as immunization and chemotherapy may modify the pathogenesis phase. Option: D. At this stage that the host's reaction to infection with a disease agent is not predictable(OPTION D). The infection may be clinical or sub-clinical, typical or atypical, or the host may become a carrier with or without having developed clinical disease, as in the case of diphtheria and poliomyelitis. The early pathogenesis phase is less dramatic in chronic diseases (e.g., coronary heart disease, hypertension, cancer). This phase in chronic diseases is referred to as the presymptomatic phase. During the presymptomatic stage, there is no manifest disease. The pathological changes are essentially below the level of the "clinical horizon." The clinical stage begins when recognizable signs or symptoms appear. By the time signs and symptoms appear, the disease phase is already well advanced into the late pathogenesis phase. Hence screening lay a role here.

questions.text: Infectivity of a disease agent implies:

options.label: C
options.text: Ability to invade & multiply in the host body

questions.correct_answer: C. Ability to invade & multiply in the host body
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ability to invade & multiply in the host body Infectivity: this is the ability of an infectious agent to invade and multiply (produce infection) in a host; Pathogenicity: this is the ability to induce clinically apparent illness, and Virulence: this is defined as the proportion of clinical cases resulting in severe clinical manifestations (including sequelae). The case fatality rate is one way of measuring virulence.

questions.text: In the Iceberg phenomenon of disease, the surface of the water acts as a demarcation between:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Apparent & Inapparent cases Disease in a community may be compared with an iceberg. The floating tip of the iceberg represents what the physician sees in the community, i.e., clinical cases. The vast submerged portion of the iceberg represents the hidden mass of disease, i.e., latent, inapparent, presymptomatic, and undiagnosed cases and carriers in the community. The "waterline" represents the demarcation between apparent and inapparent disease.

questions.text: The gap in time between the entry of the organism and the appearance of signs and symptoms is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Incubation period Incubation period: Time interval between invasion by an infectious agent and appearance of the first sign or symptom. Latent period: The interval between disease initiation and detection. It is used for non-infectious diseases as an equivalent of the incubation period. Generation time: defined as the interval between receipt of infection by a host and maximum infectivity of that host. Serial Interval: the gap in time between the onset of the primary and secondary cases.

questions.text: As a public health expert, you must estimate a new disease's incubation period. Which of the following parameters would you consider for estimating the incubation period-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Serial interval We seldom know of the incubation period of a particular disease precisely. But we know when an outbreak of disease occurs, there is an initial primary case. The primary case is followed by 2 or 3 secondary cases quickly. The gap in time between the onset of the primary case and the secondary case is called serial interval. By collecting information about a whole series of onsets, we get a distribution of secondary cases from which we can guess the disease's incubation period.

questions.text: The period between the successful entry of a pathogen and the appearance of the first clinical sign or symptom of disease is termed as-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intrinsic incubation period The time interval between invasion by an infectious agent and the appearance of the first sign or symptom of the disease in question is known as the incubation period, also called the intrinsic incubation period. Median Incubation period is the time required for 50% of the cases to occur following exposure. Extrinsic incubation period is the period between the entrance of the pathogen inside the body of the arthropod till the arthropod(vector) becomes infective. Generation time is the period between the onset of infection and the maximum infectivity of the host.

questions.text: The time in which half of the infected subjects will develop clinical manifestations following the entry of organisms into the body is known as-

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening tests, i.e., the period between diagnosis by early detection and diagnosis by other means. Generation time is the period between the onset of infection and the maximum infectivity of the host.

questions.text: The incubation period of measles is 7-14 days. A healthy susceptible known to be in contact with a case should be quarantined for a period of-

questions.text: A family had 12 members, of which 2 had a history of chickenpox. 7 members started developing symptoms of chickenpox within 3 weeks after one of the members came in contact with a case. The secondary attack rate of chickenpox would be-

Solution:

70% Secondary Attack Rate Number of exposed persons who developed disease = 7 Susceptible population= 12-2 = 10 (since out of 12 members, 2 had a history of chickenpox & hence they are no longer susceptible to the disease) So, SAR = 7/10 = 70%

questions.text: A village of 200 children under 6 years. The vaccine coverage for Measles in this age group is about 75%. If one child in the village develops Measles, and within 10-14 days, 30 other children also develop Measles. What is the S.A.R. of this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

61.2 percent Immunization coverage = 75% Therefore, 75% of children are immunized, i.e.:- 200*75/100 are immunized. =150 children are immunized Hence, The P.A.R = [1/(200-150)]*100 = 2% (total susceptible population = 50) The S.A.R = [30/ (50-1)]*100= 61.2%

questions.text: No child is completely vaccinated in a family of 5 members with 2 parents and 4 children. One of the children develops measles on April 11th, which is successfully managed. But the parents again came to the hospital with the other 2 children with similar complaints on 22nd April. What is the secondary attack rate?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

66% Option: C. 66% Secondary attack rate = (Total number of susceptible infected / Total number of susceptible exposed ) x 100= (2/3) x 100 SAR =66% Here the parents are not susceptible to measles infection, so they should be excluded Also the primary case should be excluded while calculating SAR.

questions.text: A single case of malaria was reported in a village that reported no malaria cases past few years. This is an example of:

In the given question, a single case of malaria was reported in a village where there were no malaria cases past few years. Hence it is a epidemic.

questions.text: No. of dengue cases reported this week in a village was 10 and the same village reported only 8 cases last week. This is an example of:

Solution:

Endemic Endemic refers to the constant presence of a disease or infectious agent within a given geographic area or population group without importation from outside, also referred to as the usual or expected frequency of the disease within such an area or population group. An arbitrary limit of 2 standard errors from the endemic occurrence defines an epidemic. In the given question, the village reported 8 dengue cases last week and 10 cases this week, which is within normal expectancy and not >80% or >2sd of expected frequency. Hence it is endemic.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement-

options.label: A
options.text: Occurrence of a disease that is >3 SD than the normally expected frequency is termed an epidemic.

options.label: B
options.text: Constant presence of a disease or infectious agent within a given geographic area or population group is termed endemic.

options.label: C
options.text: When an epidemic occurs in a very wide area, crossing international boundaries, it will be termed a Pandemic.

questions.correct_answer: A. Occurrence of a disease that is >3 SD than the normally expected frequency is termed an epidemic.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Occurrence of a disease that is >3 SD than the normally expected frequency is termed an epidemic. An epidemic is defined as the occurrence in a community or region of cases of an illness, specific health-related behaviour, or other health-related events clearly in excess of normal expectancy. An arbitrary limit of 2 standard deviations from the normal expected frequency is used to define the epidemic threshold for common diseases. Constant disease or infectious agent presence within a given geographic area or population group is termed endemic. It may also refer to the ‘usual’ or expected disease frequency within such area or population group. When an epidemic occurs in a very wide area, crossing international boundaries, it will be termed a Pandemic. Examples are influenza and cholera pandemics.

questions.text: Out of the following pandemics, India has not reported even a single case of-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ebola An epidemic occurring over a very wide area, crossing international boundaries, and usually affecting a large number of people is called a pandemic. Out of the given pandemics, India has not reported even a single case of Ebola Virus disease (previously known as Ebola hemorrhagic fever) Ebola appeared for the first time in Zaire & Sudan in 1976. The virus is transmitted through direct contact with blood, organs, body secretions, or other body fluids of infected animals like fruit bats. The illness is characterized by sudden onset of fever, intense weakness, muscle pain, headache, sore throat, vomiting, diarrhea, rash. Currently, there is no vaccine against Ebola.

questions.text: Influenza pandemics are known to occur at intervals of 7-10 years. This is a classical example of-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cyclic trend The disease pattern may be described by the time of its occurrence. Influenza pandemics are known to occur at intervals of 7-10 years due to antigenic variations. This type of periodic fluctuation is called a cyclic trend, as disease occurs in cycles spread over a short period which may be days, weeks, months, or years. Seasonal trend- Seasonal variation in the occurrence of disease. E.g. Measles is usually at its height in early spring. Upper respiratory infections frequently show a seasonal rise during winter months. Secular trend- This term implies changes in the occurrence of disease over a long period, generally several years or decades. Examples include coronary heart disease, lung cancer, and diabetes which have shown a consistent upward trend in developed countries during the past 50 years or so, followed by a decline of such diseases as tuberculosis, typhoid fever, diphtheria, and polio. Propagated epidemic is most often of infectious origin and results from person-to-person transmission of an infectious agent. The epidemic shows a gradual rise and tails off over a much longer period.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about the single exposure epidemic except?

questions.correct_answer: D. Always due to an infectious agent

Always due to an infectious agent In a single exposure epidemic, the exposure to the disease agent is brief. The main features are: i) the epidemic curve rises and falls rapidly with no secondary waves, ii) explosive iii) all cases develop within one incubation period. It is not always due to an infectious agent; it can also result from contamination of the environment. Example: Bhopal gas tragedy, Minamata disease in Japan Hence, among the given options, option D is the incorrect statement.

The epidemic had a quick onset and an abrupt decline as all the cases occurred suddenly when the gas was in the atmosphere. In a common source single exposure epidemic, the causative factor remains present for a brief period during which all those who come in contact become exposed to the infection. Other examples are outbreaks of food poisoning etc.

questions.text: There is an outbreak of Typhoid in a village. After the investigation, you find that the outbreak was due to a chronic carrier transmitting the disease. The correct statement about the given condition is-

options.label: A
options.text: The epidemic curve will have a single peak & all cases have occurred within 1 incubation period

options.label: B
options.text: The peak of the epidemic is not sharp & is plateau-like. The curve rises slowly and also falls slowly.

options.label: C
options.text: The epidemic is an example of a secular trend & the cases continue to appear over a very long period.

questions.correct_answer: B. The peak of the epidemic is not sharp & is plateau-like. The curve rises slowly and also falls slowly.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The peak of the epidemic is not sharp & is plateau-like. The curve rises slowly and also falls slowly. This is an example of a common source and continued exposure epidemic as the cases occurred when the infectious agent (S. typhi ) persists in the common vehicle (carrier) for some amount of time. The final decline of an epidemic occurs either because the cause of contamination is removed or because all the susceptible have become infected. The epidemic curve rises slowly and also falls gradually. The peak of the curve is not sharp; but rather plateau-like, and the duration of the epidemic is stretched out, depending on the duration for which contamination had persisted in the vehicle. The epidemic curve will have a single peak & all cases have occurred within 1 incubation period – This is the feature of a common source single exposure epidemic. Examples of secular trends are increasing cases of Ischemic heart disease and stroke, wherein the cases appear over a very long period.

questions.text: Studies in medicine are designed to identify the cause of disease. The ultimate goal of such studies is to alter the frequency or severity of these diseases. All are considerations in the determination of causality EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: Temporal sequence – causative agents must precede their consequences

options.label: C
options.text: Concurrency – cause and effect are found at the same time

questions.correct_answer: C. Concurrency – cause and effect are found at the same time
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Concurrency – cause and effect are found at the same time Determinants of causality are: Temporal association (Option A) Strength of association (Option D) Specificity of the association Consistency of the association Biological plausibility (Option B) Coherence of the association But not CONCURRENCY.

questions.text: Most important criteria to prove causal association among Hill’s criteria:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Temporal association Temporal association between two disorders or clinical problems refers to their hypothesized relationship in terms of the time of onset, most often inferring a causal or contributory relationship. Refers to “cause precedes effect” or “Exposure to outcome.”
